Input.posts:
Does anyone understand why the directory line address 4096 for P1 is set to 'share' at time 8 and not to 'exclusive' as I would expect? I would have expected the line to be in Exclusive {P1} state. When P1 refers to line 4100, since direct mapped cache of 4 kB, it points to block 0 w/ a tag of 4096 and offset of 4. The request is a miss, so P1 that had the line zero at block zero at time 7 has to write back the line at physical address 0 and set the line address 0 to invalid. However, block at address 0 has a new content from main memory address 4100, why is this line address of 4096 not in exclusive at this point but instead in 'share' state although it was invalid before?
Upvotes:
0
Hi Joseph, \xA0 The reason is that the Processor caches are following a MSI protocol, and not a MESI protocol. \xA0It would have moved to an exclusive state for a MESI protocol.\xA0 \xA0 You have suggested the right transitions for the MESI - \xA0At Time 8,you have a Read miss due to the Load word for the Cache line address 4096. As you correctly point out, the Cache line is going to be evicted ( since it was reserved for Address 0 ), and then refilled with the data for 4096. \xA0\xA0You may think of this as though the Cache line at address 4096 was initially in an Invalid state initially and then you have a read miss, therefore the transition would occur from the 'I' to the 'S' state as per the MSI state machine ( for a Read miss ).\xA0\xA0If you had a Load word at time 8 for the address 0, then you would have seen the state machine to remain in 'Modified' state. Regards, Pushkal

Since it is a Read miss on Time Slot 8, the Directory State machine shall transition to the 'Shared' state ( Slide 16 of Slide Deck 15 ). Had it been a Write miss, it would have transitioned to the 'E' state.
